headline.main: Food companies are urged to act to deflect blame for the nation's increase in obesity.

docs.abstract: Many brand experts are urging food industry to act to deflect blame by health advocates and lawyers for country's growing obesity problem; suggested actions include posting more nutrition information more prominently, offering smaller portions, developing healthier menus and generally expressing more concern over obesity; Center for Consumer Freedom, group representing restaurants and food companies, asserts that blaming food companies for obesity is mistake; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HEALTH advocates and lawyers are increasingly trying to blame food companies for the country's growing obesity problem, borrowing tactics that anti-smoking advocates have used successfully against tobacco companies and their addictive products. While marketers and others may scoff at lawsuits like the one two New York teenagers filed against McDonald's, accusing it of failing to provide necessary information about health risks associated with its meals, some analysts and brand experts assert that food companies have ignored the developments at their peril.

docs.lead_paragraph: Board Shuffle at Disney Appears Likely to Aid Eisner The Walt Disney Company announced several changes to its board, including one that could reduce the influence of a chief critic of Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive. As part of the boardroom changes, Disney will add an independent director. It will also reconfigure the board committees and conduct two meetings a year without company executives present. In addition, Disney said it was lowering its 2002 earnings estimate because of last weekend's disastrous performance of the animated ''Treasure Planet,'' which cost $140 million to make but took in only $17 million at the domestic box office over the weekend. [Page C4.]

headline.main: Get the Weight Off: Healthy Ideas

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Louis Flancbaum says more research funds are needed to study morbid obesity and effects of surgical treatment described in Nov 24 editorial
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Drastic Surgery for Drastic Obesity'' (editorial, Nov. 24): For many suffering with morbid obesity, access to weight loss surgery is all too often denied by insurance carriers, including Medicare. These carriers either do not recognize morbid obesity as a disease or they place so many arbitrary obstacles in the path of patients that approval becomes impossible. A legislative remedy is sorely needed.
